clues: Alice doesn't live in the red house
The person with the cat lives in the blue house
Carol doesn't live in the green house
questions: Who lives in the red house?
What color house does Bob live in?

Saruman doesn't carry the willow staff

questions: What color room does Ben use?

math_puzzle.description: If 2 cats catch 2 mice in 2 minutes, how many cats are needed to catch 100 mice in 50 minutes?
math_puzzle.explanation: Rate is 1 cat per 1 mouse per 2 minutes. In 50 minutes, 1 cat catches 25 mice. So 4 cats catch 100 mice.

math_puzzle.description: A farmer has chickens and rabbits. There are 35 heads and 94 feet total. How many chickens are there?
math_puzzle.explanation: Let c=chickens, r=rabbits. c+r=35, 2c+4r=94. Solving: r=12, c=23.

math_puzzle.description: In a race, you overtake the person in 2nd place. What position are you in now?
math_puzzle.explanation: If you overtake the person in 2nd place, you take their position.

math_puzzle.description: A man lives on the 20th floor of an apartment building. Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor. When he comes home, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and walks the rest of the way... except on rainy days, when he takes the elevator all the way to the 20th floor. Why?
math_puzzle.explanation: He's too short to reach the button for the 20th floor, except when he has an umbrella on rainy days.

mechanical.description: You have 12 balls that look identical. One ball is either heavier or lighter than the others. Using a balance scale only 3 times, how do you find the different ball and determine if it's heavier or lighter?
mechanical.explanation: Divide into 3 groups of 4. Weigh two groups. If balanced, the different ball is in the third group. If unbalanced, it's in one of the weighed groups. Continue subdividing.

mechanical.description: You have a 3-gallon jug and a 5-gallon jug. How do you measure exactly 4 gallons of water?
mechanical.answer: fill 5, pour into 3, empty 3, pour remaining 2 from 5 into 3, fill 5 again, pour into 3 until full
mechanical.explanation: Fill 5-gallon jug, pour into 3-gallon (leaving 2 in the 5-gallon). Empty 3-gallon, pour the 2 gallons into it. Fill 5-gallon again, pour into 3-gallon until full (1 gallon), leaving 4 gallons in the 5-gallon jug.
